search_results.title: Washing Machine Heart
search_results.lyrics:
TranslationsEspañolWashing Machine Heart Lyrics[Verse 1]
Toss your dirty shoes in my washing machine heart
Baby, bang it up inside
I'm not wearing my usual lipstick
I thought maybe we would kiss tonight

[Pre-Chorus]
Baby, will you kiss me already?
And toss your dirty shoes in my washing machine heart
Baby, bang it up inside
[Instrumental Chorus]

[Verse 2]
Baby, though I've closed my eyes
I know who you pretend I am
I know who you pretend I am

[Bridge]
But, do-mi-ti
Why not me? Why not me?
Do-mi-ti
Why not me? Why not me?

[Chorus]
Do-mi-ti
Why not me? Why not me?You might also like65Embed

description.plain:
“Washing Machine Heart”, the twelfth track off Be the Cowboy, is sonically upbeat, but lyrically explores the “manic” nature of Mitski’s protagonist, who, in her words:

…is a person who’s in me. It’s just I’m not this person all the time. It’s this woman who feels powerless and overcompensates by exercising extreme control on herself and on her environment, and just trying to be powerful within her own limits of her body and who she is, but kind of just unraveling a little bit because the amount of control she’s exercising on to herself maybe isn’t healthy or isn’t natural. There’s something more warm and human inside that she’s pushing down in order to appear strong to the world."

The heavy backbeat in the track may represent the clatter of a washing machine and how it parallels the feverish thrum of Mitski (or her protagonist)’s heart.

…is a person who’s in me. It’s just I’m not this person all the time. It’s this woman who feels powerless and overcompensates by exercising extreme control on herself and on her environment, and just trying to be powerful within her own limits of her body and who she is, but kind of just unraveling a little bit because the amount of control she’s exercising on to herself maybe isn’t healthy or isn’t natural. There’s something more warm and human inside that she’s pushing down in order to appear strong to the world."

The heavy backbeat in the track may represent the clatter of a washing machine and how it parallels the feverish thrum of Mitski (or her protagonist)’s heart.

annotations: Baby, will you kiss me already?

This lyric could possibly show how her mindset has conditioned her to silence herself if she tries to get control in favour of being powerless.

The line emphasises the same idea as the last two. But likely, you could say that it is reinforcing the pov being impatient. And given the themes of repetition in the album… it could be that the protagonist is starting to become tired of waiting for love.
Why not me? Why not me?

This could be a continuation of the previous line I know who you pretend I am, saying “I know the version of me that you have made in your head, but why not me? Am I not good enough?”

It could also suggest that there is another person; be it the “other woman” or perhaps an ex that her lover still cares.

I’m not wearing my usual lipstick
 I thought maybe we would kiss tonight

The narrator has to put on a different persona – a different lipstick – in order to kiss this person. Their true self is not desirable enough either in their opinion or in the subject’s opinion. This feeling of inadequacy is a common thread in much of Mitski’s work.

This also shows her desire to be pursued romantically (simply kissing) and not be seen as someone who solely provides sex and performs care tasks.

The “usual lipstick” implies that they usually don’t kiss although she wants to, so she’s hoping that tonight might be an exception. This shows that there’s a lack of real affection and connection in the relationship, and might imply that she’s not valued in the relationship or she has things she wants to do but has not voiced out to her lover. Communication is the key to relationships and therefore, this shows that this relationship might not be the healthiest.

Baby, though I’ve closed my eyes
 I know who you pretend I am
 I know who you pretend I am

By saying that she closed her eyes she may mean she is pretending to not see the way her lover lies about who she really is, maybe painting her as an idealized version of herself. She’s telling them she is aware of this even though she pretends not to notice.

Alternatively, the lines may refer to the fact that he is thinking of somebody else when they are together, he is pretending she is the person who he really wants to be with.

Also, it is very common to close eyes before kissing.
But, do-mi-ti

These solfege symbols (as in ”do-re-mi-fa-so-la-ti”) correspond with the pitch at which each note is sung.

Mitski sings “do mi ti, why not me?” analogizing the way her lover hears the notes but not the words, the beautiful performance but not authentic self behind the facade.

And toss your dirty shoes in my washing machine heart
 Baby, bang it up inside

Mitski talking with Rob Hakimian from The 405:


The main image of ‘Washing Machine Heart’ gives me an idea of peaceful domesticity. Why did you choose it?

“It’s about your heart beating so loud that it’s going DUNDUN – DUN. Like there’s a shoe in it.”

I was thinking about how the washing machine is very useful, but it’s also quite unglamorous the job it has to do…

“Yeah, people just carelessly toss their dirty shoes in there.”

Yeah, they just take whatever throw at them and they’re happy to do it.

“There is that too… there can be more than one meaning.”

Toss your dirty shoes in my washing machine heart
 Baby, bang it up inside

Being stuck in repeating patterns and going around in circles are a recurring theme on this album, as demonstrated by “A Horse Named Cold Air”, for example. Washing machines clean, just as Mitski is expected to perform emotional labor for her significant other, in the process forgetting who she is, becoming almost an appliance. In the process of trying to fix her partner, her own heart is taking the damage.

The shoes in particular could allude to washing someone else’s feet. In the Bible, Jesus washes the feet of his disciples as an act of humility and selflessness. This can be connected to Mitski, who feels obligated to serve her partner.
The shoes could also represent Mitski’s partner. We wear shoes whenever we leave the house and they gather dirt everywhere we go. This could represent the emotional baggage that her partner has collected throughout their life.

description.plain: The title “First Love/Late Spring” is a juxtaposition, mirroring the turmoil of the song’s themes of restlessness and unease. “First love” is a common theme in music, usually presented as something naive and innocent. “Late spring”, on the other hand, suggests the difficulties of the first love, as the youth of spring transitions to the harsh realities of summer.

annotations: One word from you and I would

Mitski is so in love with the partner shes singing about that she would dedicate her entire existence to them, risks and dangers of it becoming irrelevant due to love blinding her rational judgement. They could say anything and she would do, even if it involved jumping off a ledge.

This lyric could also refer to the idea that if only her lover chose to say that little word, and if they wanted to stop the relationship, Mitski would abandon the ledge that is her obsession, with its development making sense due to the implication that Mitskis mentality is childlike (children tend to attach to people they admire) and also unexperienced as it is her first love, representing the way it affects her thinking and view of things, much like seeing a view from a high point. Like that, the rejection becomes beneficial on both sides: the person gets what they want and Mitski is freed from feeling so miserable. Mitski is craving to get rid of the desperate feeling she’s had from a relationship that seems to be going wrong and a fragile mental state, and asks to be freed from it by her partner who she admires and who’s word she will always consider
One word from you and I would

Mitski is so in love with the partner shes singing about that she would dedicate her entire existence to them, risks and dangers of it becoming irrelevant due to love blinding her rational judgement. They could say anything and she would do, even if it involved jumping off a ledge.

This lyric could also refer to the idea that if only her lover chose to say that little word, and if they wanted to stop the relationship, Mitski would abandon the ledge that is her obsession, with its development making sense due to the implication that Mitskis mentality is childlike (children tend to attach to people they admire) and also unexperienced as it is her first love, representing the way it affects her thinking and view of things, much like seeing a view from a high point. Like that, the rejection becomes beneficial on both sides: the person gets what they want and Mitski is freed from feeling so miserable. Mitski is craving to get rid of the desperate feeling she’s had from a relationship that seems to be going wrong and a fragile mental state, and asks to be freed from it by her partner who she admires and who’s word she will always consider
One word from you and I would

Mitski is so in love with the partner shes singing about that she would dedicate her entire existence to them, risks and dangers of it becoming irrelevant due to love blinding her rational judgement. They could say anything and she would do, even if it involved jumping off a ledge.

This lyric could also refer to the idea that if only her lover chose to say that little word, and if they wanted to stop the relationship, Mitski would abandon the ledge that is her obsession, with its development making sense due to the implication that Mitskis mentality is childlike (children tend to attach to people they admire) and also unexperienced as it is her first love, representing the way it affects her thinking and view of things, much like seeing a view from a high point. Like that, the rejection becomes beneficial on both sides: the person gets what they want and Mitski is freed from feeling so miserable. Mitski is craving to get rid of the desperate feeling she’s had from a relationship that seems to be going wrong and a fragile mental state, and asks to be freed from it by her partner who she admires and who’s word she will always consider
Tell me, ”Don’t”, so I can crawl back in

when someone is about to end their life all someone can do is tell them “not to” or “don’t” they obviously mean what they’re saying but is that really enough? its enough to keep the person alive but not keep the person happy and content. This person will tell Mitski “not to do it” and when she doesn’t he will leave her once again and she will “crawl back in”

The black hole of the window where you sleep
 The night breeze carries something sweet, a peach tree

Before Mitski got famous she had a cheeky little hole in her window. This little black hole takes in a sweet breeze, and the smell of the peach tree that was outside her window at the time.

Some people might interpret as if the hole is a metaphor for something or someone, that even tho someone is ruining something that would’ve been so clear and easy, that theres still is something sweet and nice in it.

That sweet breeze that comes from black hole in her window could also represent the little hope that comes in life every once in a while.

The “black hole” may refer to an empty space,  meaning that the person/lover who slept there is not there anymore. This would maybe help to understand why Mitski said afterwards “Wild women don’t get the blues.” It means she was sad and she could’ve been sad because her lover was no longer sleeping there.

So please, hurry, leave me, I can’t breathe
 Please don’t say you love me

Mitski’s love for this person is so intense that she wants them to leave so she’s relieved of this overwhelming emotion. If they said they loved her, it would only solidify the feeling and make everything more real, which is a terrifying prospect for her.
[Instrumental Bridge]

This interlude almost feels like a momentary release, a brief surrender to the suffocating longing the narrator feels.

Modulation to a higher key in pop music is commonly understood to announce the song’s climactic finish (see Whitney Houston’s “I Will Always Love You” for a popular example). In most of these cases, the song either maintains the new key to its conclusion or modulates again to a higher key. Here, however, the key is only briefly maintained and is quickly cut off by the outro.

Mitski’s choice to return to the original key after modulating deprives the interlude of a satisfying resolution and instills a sense of disappointment in the listener. This mirrors the song’s themes of frustration. It is a momentary lapse of restraint anxiously interrupted by a return to denial.

And I don’t wanna go home yet
 Let me walk to the top of the big night sky

Throughout the song Mitski references “crying like a tall child” and “I’ve grown in to a tall child”, the way I interpreted this line was that as a child you always say to your parents “I don’t want to go home yet” and her referencing that in the song is almost a childlike thing to say so it carries the theme of the song, of being an adult but still “acting” and feeling like a child.

The last line ties back to the “ledge” she’s found herself on. There’s some childlike sense of adventure in the idea of walking to the top of big night sky, but she doesn’t want to go home yet (feeling intoxicated) and wanders up to the top of the night sky (possibly related to the feeling like you’re high or like you’re floating when you’re in love), but it’s sandwiched between the chorus of feeling overwhelmed and too much, like you’re stuck up on a ledge way up high and need to be helped off. Like a child who’s in over their head.

But I find that
 Lately, I’ve been crying like a tall child

Being a “tall child” can be interpreted as having a child like maturity or mind set while being stuck in Mitski’s adult body. In this statement, she could be saying that lately she (in her adult form) has been crying in a way she hasn’t since she was a child or in a manner that she associates as childish. Mitski continues to use this phrasing of “tall child” later in the song when she sings, “And I was so young when I behaved twenty five. Yet now I find I’ve grown into a tall child."

And I was so young when I behaved twenty-five
 Yet now, I find I’ve grown into a tall child

Here, Mitski explains how she felt more mature in her childhood than she does or did as an adult in this relationship. She is described as a “tall” child, meaning that she sees her self-worth as that of a child in an adult body. This showcases to us that the relationship she was/is in made her highly dependant (like a child). It could also mean that she finds herself being more emotional right now as an adult, than she ever did as a child.

The line “I was so young when I behaved twenty five” may also mean that people told her from a young age that she was very mature for her age so she adapted that into her personality in order to not disappoint them (we’ve seen from songs like “Real Men” that she’s learned to need male validation, so maybe a father figure pushed this idea on her and so she wanted to please them by acting the way they wanted her to). This led to her hiding her true feelings and probably missing out on on a lot from her childhood. Now that she she’s grown, she realises the trauma these people have caused her and so she tries to live these “childish” feeling she never was allowed to have.

I don't know what to do without you
I don't know where to put my hands
I've been trying to lay my head down

[Chorus]

[Verse 2]
On sunny days, I go out walking
I end up on a tree-lined street
I look up at the gaps of sunlight
I miss you more than anything

[Chorus]
I don't need the world to see
That I've been the best I can be, but
I don't think I could stand to be
Where you don't see me

[Outro]
And autumn comes when you're not yet done
With the summer passing by, but
I don't think I could stand to be
Where you don't see meYou might also like25Embed

description.plain:
With a powerful melody carried by a tired voice, “Francis Forever” presents itself as a dark soft ballad that builds towards an epic ending, with some grunge influences.

Like in much of her music, Mitski reflects upon her isolation and feelings of inadequacy (possibly after the loss of a lover). The “Francis” in the title itself is a reference to the artist’s middle name, referring to the secrecy and hidden nature of these perpetual feelings.

The song was covered by Marceline in the episode “The Music Hole” from Cartoon Network’s Adventure Time.

Like in much of her music, Mitski reflects upon her isolation and feelings of inadequacy (possibly after the loss of a lover). The “Francis” in the title itself is a reference to the artist’s middle name, referring to the secrecy and hidden nature of these perpetual feelings.

songs.title: Francis Forever (Ελληνική Μετάφραση /Greek Translation)

annotations:
I’ve been trying to lay my head down
 But I’m writing this at 3 a.m

She is trying to get to sleep and move on over this loss of love be she cant help herself longing for her ex. She says “but” as if she has found herself in this situation and had little to no control over herself writing this song.

Alternatively, it’s very difficult to ignore your creative voice when the mood strikes. It often prevents writers from resting when they’re “trying to lay” their “head(s)” down, forcing them to see ideas through even at inconvenient times like 3 in the morning.

I don’t know what to do without you
 I don’t know where to put my hands

In this line she could be stating the end of the relationship was abrupt and she feels so lost without her lover that she cant even do simple things like act naturally, in her hand placement.

In the case that this is a song about yearning to make music, as Mitski has stated she sometimes does, “I don’t know what to do without you” could reference feeling an emptiness when she’s not giving herself to her craft and “I don’t know where to put my hands” would refer more specifically to feeling purposeless without an instrument at hand.

And autumn comes when you’re not yet done
 With the summer passing by, but

This continues the seasons motif explored throughout the album, directly succeeding late spring and moving past summer into the autumn/early winter of Jobless Monday.

This could also hint at the tendency for songs and albums to take longer than artists usually want in the interests of fleshing them out fully, so much so that by the end of the production cycle they feel like they’re in a different season of their life, so to speak.

On sunny days, I go out walking
 I end up on a tree-lined street
 I look up at the gaps of sunlight

Komorebi (木漏れ日), is a Japanese phrase with no direct translation to the English language. Komorebi refers to the interplay between the light and leaves when sunlight shines through trees. Komorebi is commonly used to refer to the nostalgia and melancholic longing for a person far away.

Part of Mitski’s trademark in songwriting lies in setting vibrant imagery. This verse is similar in nature to one from “First Love/Late Spring”:

The black hole of the window where you sleep
The night breeze carries, something sweet
A peach tree

And this from “Carry Me Out”:

At night on the rooftop
I untie my hair
And watch from my plastic chair
As my dark hair unleashes the night
The scent of flowers
Still in bloom from morning shower
I miss you more than anything

The power of this line comes from the jarring way in which it seems as if it’s blurted out uncontrollably. The narrator is walking, meandering, day-dreaming, trying to distract herself, but simply can’t hold it in anymore.

I don’t need the world to see
 That I’ve been the best I can be, but
 I don’t think I could stand to be
 Where you don’t see me

The chorus presents the central issue of the song: the narrator is torn between not caring what people think about her and depending on her former lover’s perception of her, which she can’t stand to be without.

Alternatively, Mitski isn’t up for expressing her feelings or explaining her unfavourable actions. This song is her last attempt to repair what is lost. It’s to show she’s not able to accept she’s no longer a major role in their lives.  This song might be the aftermath of “First Love/Late Spring,” a relationship’s start. There’s no explanation for them breaking up. There’s just her upset it happened.

Though she is trying to say as much as she wants to keep herself and her improvements as a person private, she is willing to put all of that out in the open for the attention of the lover that we can assume left her.

Through the lens of romance as a metaphor for pursuing music, the chorus may also allude to Mitski not needing the audience and music industry to see how hard she’s been trying, but she can’t bare to leave this career path behind.

description.plain:
Mitski’s ninth track off her 2018 album Be the Cowboy, “Nobody” was released as a single on June 26.

The song touches on themes of alienation and estrangement, but over a disco-paced beat, it’s hard not to want to dance the lonesome away.

body.plain:
Mitski’s ninth track off her 2018 album Be the Cowboy, “Nobody” was released as a single on June 26.

The song touches on themes of alienation and estrangement, but over a disco-paced beat, it’s hard not to want to dance the lonesome away.

annotations: And I know no one will save me,
mitski accepts her defeat; she knows that theres no point in wanting, but instead recognizing that she needs it.
And I know no one will save me,

Alluding to the fact that no person, no matter how great they are, can fix your issues for you. Whatever Mitski is working through, she knows it is up to her to do it. However, despite this, she still feels the natural urge to be with someone.

I’ve been big and small and big and small and big and small again
 And still nobody wants me, still nobody wants me

That was literal, like I have gained weight and I’ve lost weight and I’ve been big and I’ve been small. I’ve tried this clothes, I’ve had this hair cut. I’ve done everything I could to my body and still nobody wants me. Just like what will it take? What will it take to be wanted? What do I need to do to be desirable? That’s where it came from.

This line is reminiscent of the first verse from her earlier song “Townie” from her 2014 album Bury Me at Makeout Creek:

‘Cause we’ve tried hungry and we’ve tried full
And nothing seems enough

Both songs are about craving love and not fulfilling others expectations.
And I’ll be alright

Speaking on this lyric with The 405:


The “one good movie kiss and I’ll be alright” in ‘Nobody’ line makes me wonder if you have any particular favourite movie kisses?

“The only thing that’s popping up in my head is The Notebook [laughs]. It’s just very, very heavy handed romantic stuff.”

I just need someone to kiss
 Give me one good honest kiss

Kisses, and the need to be kissed, are a recurring motif throughout this album. When asked why she rarely disclosed anything more sordid, Mitski responded:

I take everything seriously. I don’t wanna get into my sex life. A kiss means something to me.”

When the pre-chorus is repeated, Mitski changes the kiss she craves from an ‘honest’ kiss to a ‘movie’ kiss, possibly highlighting how deep her loneliness has developed throughout the song. She no longer craves an honest, loving, and intimate kiss, but will settle for what she can get to feel that intimacy. It may not be “real”, but her loneliness is so consuming that she doesn’t care.

A “movie kiss” could also mean that the kiss would be dramatic in the ways that it isn’t always in real life. In movies, kisses are always climactic, and that kind of raw impact is what Mitski might crave to distract from her loneliness. While talking to London in Stereo, she mentioned how vital movies were to this new album:

A lot of this album is just about cinema, and the effect of watching a movie or being in a movie. Growing up a lot of my relationships were fantasies. I didn’t have a chance to get to know people or build real relationships. I don’t know what the draw of infatuation is, but I know that it helped me survive when I was younger.

Nobody, nobody, nobody, nobody, nobody
 Ooh, nobody, nobody, nobody

Not only is Mitski mourning her loneliness, that nobody wants her, but following the theme of the third verse, she also seems to be dissatisfied with her own body. The chorus becomes an existential plea with “nobody” beginning to sound like “no body.”

In the Genius interview, Mitski said she hates to admit it, but she was on the floor just repeating “nobody” to herself because she felt so alone. She felt as if she didn’t matter.

I’ve been big and small and big and small and big and small again
 And still nobody wants me, still nobody wants me

That was literal, like I have gained weight and I’ve lost weight and I’ve been big and I’ve been small. I’ve tried this clothes, I’ve had this hair cut. I’ve done everything I could to my body and still nobody wants me. Just like what will it take? What will it take to be wanted? What do I need to do to be desirable? That’s where it came from.
And I don’t want your pity, I just want somebody near me

Pity is an emotion you have for someone who’s like lower than you. I don’t want your fucking pity. Can you just sit next to me? Don’t even talk. Just please don’t talk. Just be next to me and I want to feel another human being, being around me and that’s it. Don’t judge me.
Venus, planet of love,

I read an article that said the planet Venus at some point in its history actually experienced global warming. I can’t source the article right now, I don’t exactly know where it came from, but I know I read it somewhere. I thought, “Oh it would be funny if Venus, which is the planet of love actually had a civilization on it at some point and the people of Venus wanted so much and wanted too much that they just used up all their resources.”

My God, I’m so lonely, so I open the window
 To hear sounds of people, to hear sounds of people

I was in Kuala Lumpur and I was in KLCC, which is the city center and I subletted a little studio apartment. I literally just opened the windows to hear other people being alive. Kuala Lumpur is really vibrant, like there are a lot of city sounds.

Malaysia is a tropical country, so it’s summer all year round. Even in the city center, there are trees everywhere and there’s a lot of traffic, a lot of cars, a lot of different kinds of people living. It’s just a really vibrant country and city. It’s kind of like New York City. I don’t think as many people as New York City, but definitely just as much honking as New York City.

description.plain:
“Me and My Husband” is the seventh track of Mitski’s fifth studio album Be The Cowboy released in August 2018.
Like earlier tracks on the album such as ‘Nobody’, ‘Me and My Husband’ explores the loneliness Mitski felt while writing the album, although this time she takes on the persona of a suburban housewife. As she explained to GQ:

If you’re a suburban mom surrounded by family with a nice life you still feel alone. On tour, I’m surrounded by people all the time but it’s lonely.

Despite the songs upbeat tone the lyrics portray a housewife stubbornly sticking by her husband even though she may not be happy. Mitski claims the song isn’t personal and isn’t meant to be reflection of her views on marriage or settling down as she told The Outline:

I try to keep a sense of humor about all this stuff. I’m not married, I don’t have a husband, but I was just thinking about being a woman with a man in a long term relationship. I used a stereotype of the suburban, old-fashioned housewife to kind of accentuate my point.

Like earlier tracks on the album such as ‘Nobody’, ‘Me and My Husband’ explores the loneliness Mitski felt while writing the album, although this time she takes on the persona of a suburban housewife. As she explained to GQ:

If you’re a suburban mom surrounded by family with a nice life you still feel alone. On tour, I’m surrounded by people all the time but it’s lonely.

Despite the songs upbeat tone the lyrics portray a housewife stubbornly sticking by her husband even though she may not be happy. Mitski claims the song isn’t personal and isn’t meant to be reflection of her views on marriage or settling down as she told The Outline:

I try to keep a sense of humor about all this stuff. I’m not married, I don’t have a husband, but I was just thinking about being a woman with a man in a long term relationship. I used a stereotype of the suburban, old-fashioned housewife to kind of accentuate my point.

annotations: We are doing better

This could be the toxic ideal that a divorce is not an option and you can only get married once. This has caused so much of the “Boomer Humor” jokes like “I hate my wife” or “I hate my husband. She could be trying to hold on to the remnants of the relationship and what it used to be. It could be a lie she tells others when in fact its not getting better. It could be tied in with Washing Machine Heart where she keeps giving and her lover is not. How he uses her as a ‘Washing Machine’ to ‘clean out’ his problems. And what happens if you dont take care of your washing machine? It builds up with gunk and limescale and eventually breaks.
With my eyes, with my body, with me
It shows how everything will disappear or more so theoretically.  It shows how senses are heavily relied on this

Me and my husband
 We are doing better
Repetition of “Me and my husband we are doing better” seems as though shes trying to convince herself their relationship is improving although it isn’t
But me and my husband

The repetition of me and my husband throughout the song may show the psychological and the physical dependency that Mitski has on him. As a listener, it makes me believe that the thought of not being with someone scares the life out of her

And at least in this lifetime
 We’re sticking together
 Me and my husband
 We’re sticking together

Mitski isn’t married but assumed the role of a stereotypical housewife while writing this song. She explained the mindset behind this character who remained with their husband despite being unhappy  to The Outline:

There’s something about being the person in the relationship who is dependent on the other person — whether it’s financially or it’s just in terms of identity — and maybe not being happy, but saying, “This is the life I chose and this is the person I chose and this is my identity, so I’m going to hold onto it and I’m going to do this until I die. Maybe in the next lifetime I will be somebody else. But in this lifetime I’m sticking with my husband. I am maintaining my position in this relationship. And it doesn’t matter if I’m happy."

It’s always been just him and me
 Together

This theme of eternal domesticity was explored in Mitski’s previous album, in the track “Fireworks” by Mitski  :

I will be married to silence,
The gentleman won’t say a word
But you know, oh you know in the quiet he holds
Runs a river that will never find home

This could also be a reference to the first verse; now that she is married she no longer has her memories or her identity. Now her only sense of identity is her husband and their relationship. She is no longer an individual.

And I’m the idiot with the painted face
 In the corner, taking up space
 But when he walks in, I am loved, I am loved

This may be a reference to Mitski feeling the need to be a different person for the people she’s interested in. This is demonstrated in her cover art where she sports makeup on her face, or in the song “Your Best American Girl”.

And you’re an all-American boy
I guess I couldn’t help trying to be your best American girl

Taken at its most literal, this lyric states that when it comes to her husband she feels loved for who she is.

However it’s more likely that this line describes how unhealthy the character’s relationship is. It’s reminiscent of a previous song on Be the Cowboy, “Lonesome Love” as it describes how the characters self-worth is purely based on her partner.

‘Cause nobody butters me up like you, and
Nobody fucks me like me

She is also portraying a stereotypically feminine woman in a world that doesn’t always value women and therefore may be feeling disempowered by her place in the world. She only feels validated by her husband, the male presence in her life.

So I bet all I have on that
 Furrowed brow

A furrowed brow usually comes with age, and it may, then, indicate a desire for a relationship that stands the test of time.



A furrowed brow is also a facial expression usually expressing frustration or judgement. As Mitski takes on the role of a stereotypical housewife, her husband is likely a masculine stereotype as well and therefore cold or aggressive. Her character is desperate for affection from her husband but he simply stands in judgement. She told London In Stereo that the song was inspired by the relationships she saw in films as a child which often rely heavily on stereotypes:

It’s a fantasy formed from Mitski’s childhood, which she spent “just watching movies and assuming that’s how love is, and wanting that.”

A furrowed brow describes a partner that is more angry or serious, which overall describes negative emotions that may exude from the partner. The fact that she is willing to bet all she has on even the negative parts of her partner explains the dependence that exists within the relationship. Although marriage and relationships require compromise and fights become inevitable, women have historically been forced to find a partner and stick with them through anything. Even just decades ago, divorce was seen as a really scandalous idea which was avoided in fear of judgment from other people.
[Chorus]

Mitski discussing the song in an interview with The 405:

It’s interesting that you decided to make it into a song though, considering you’re not married…

I think a big part of me is retaliating against youth culture, because I’m getting older, but I’m in the entertainment business, where I’m expected to be young forever and sing about going to the club and being infatuated with someone and having your first love. But I’m 27, like…

You’ve got some of those things covered, maybe not the club part but the infatuation part…

Exactly! But I can’t keep doing that and still being truthful, because the reality is I’m an adult now, and I’m getting older, and you get older you see a lot of sides of love, and you experience relationships that aren’t just your first love. I think so much of music is so youth-oriented, when there are so many more stories to tell. A pop song doesn’t just have to be about that young love, because there’s so many more experiences that are worth singing about.
I steal a few breaths from the world for a minute

She’s talking about the shortness of life. We are only here for a “few minutes” where we breathe and then die.

Describing breathing as “stealing a few breaths” conveys the feelings of smallness. The air doesn’t belong to anyone, we are all free to breathe it. Yet Mitski paints the image of someone who feels unworthy to be allowed to leave – probably sinking to the bottom of self-esteem after the high expectations of defeating oblivion.

search_results.full_title: I Bet on Losing Dogs by Mitski
search_results.title: I Bet on Losing Dogs
search_results.lyrics:
I Bet on Losing Dogs Lyrics[Verse]
My baby, my baby
You're my baby, say it to me
Baby, my baby
Tell your baby that I'm your baby

[Chorus]
I bet on losing dogs
I know they're losing and I pay for my place
By the ring, where I'll be looking in their eyes when they're down
I'll be there on their side, I'm losing by their side
[Bridge]
Will you let me, baby

[Chorus 2]
Lose on losing dogs?
I know they're losing and I pay for my place
By the ring, where I'll be looking in their eyes when they're down
I wanna feel it, I bet on losing dogs
I always want you when I'm finally fine
How you'd be over me looking in my eyes when I come

[Outro]
Someone to watch me die, someone to watch me die
I bet on losing dogs (Did you get that?)You might also like49Embed

description.plain:
The “losing dogs” or failed relationships that Mitski pursues. This represents a sort of unrequited love in which Mitski’s feelings are not reciprocated with the same intensity.
The use of “baby” in the song could allude to how she wants someone to care for and to be cared for in return.

The metaphor of ‘betting on losing dogs’ refers to Mitski getting into relationships that she knows are doomed, or with people who are too damaged to love her – she knows that it will inevitably end badly, but she consciously gets into a relationship regardless.

She’s asking them to let her keep believing in the illusion that they are gonna work out or that they are gonna love her back one day.

It also alludes to the idea that she, herself, is a losing dog. She hopes that her lover will be there to comfort her when she is down, just as she does.

Anticipating the theme of “Thursday Girl”, in these lines, the narrator sings about her desire to feel the pain in defeat of rejection.

She longs for the intimacy and connection formed with her lover. An orgasm is known as a “little death” (from the french term “la petite mort”).

Her lover looks in her eyes, rather than Mitski looking in the eyes of the losing dogs. This reversal is interesting.

Also, the mention of orgasm could be a reference to Happy, perhaps contrasting the experience of being with a ‘losing’ lover with the experience of unsustainable happiness.

The “losing dogs” or failed relationships that Mitski pursues. This represents a sort of unrequited love in which Mitski’s feelings are not reciprocated with the same intensity.

annotations:
My baby, my baby
 You’re my baby, say it to me
 Baby, my baby
 Tell your baby that I’m your baby

Mistki is telling her significant other that they’re her baby over and over again, asking them to call her their baby back to her, seemingly as a reassurance that they won’t leave her, stated by “tell your baby that I’m your baby”, meaning they may have another that they’re abandoning her for, and she knows this.
By the ring
A metaphor on mariage or commitment
I wanna feel it

Mitski finds comfort in sadness and pain, this is hinted to throughout Puberty 2 but this line shows that she really wants to experience the raw heartbreak over and over in these failing relationships to cure the numbness and to know she is still existing.
I always want you when I’m finally fine

Making bets, gambling, etc. are addictions. She is in a constant cycle of betting, and when she is “finally fine” her addiction just brings her back to it. Of course, this is also to be taken as an analogy to Mitski’s pursuit of unrequited love, in which she consistently finds new people to yearn for whom she’s aware will never feel the same.
Will you let me, baby

Mitski is metaphorically saying that she is betting and struggling in a relationship that she knows will not come to nothing, she is betting on losing dogs (losing dogs is a reference to dog racing games with bets, and she bets on dogs that are losing, knowing that she will lose, but she’s not bothered by it).

I bet on losing dogs
 I know they’re losing and I pay for my place
 By the ring, where I’ll be looking in their eyes when they’re down
 I’ll be there on their side, I’m losing by their side

‘Losing dogs’ could suggest these dogs are fighting dogs, who have lost. Many fighting dogs who lose sustain injuries during the fight and are starved and beaten after losing making them weak.
When Mitski says she bets on ‘losing dogs’ she is alluding to the fact she gets into relationships that she knows are destined to end badly and maybe with the wrong people as she has no confidence in love.
She says she is ‘there on their side’ which shows that having been in a failed relationship or relationship that is abusive, she is left (emotionally) feeling abused, tired, and used.
She ‘looks in their eyes when they’re down’ implying a sort of empathy she has with them. she recognizes herself in these metaphorical losing dogs who are tired, abused, and unhappy.
How you’d be over me looking in my eyes when I come

She longs for the intimacy and connection formed with her lover. An orgasm is known as a “little death” (from the french term “la petite mort”).

Her lover looks in her eyes, rather than Mitski looking in the eyes of the losing dogs. This reversal is interesting.

Also, the mention of orgasm could be a reference to Happy, perhaps contrasting the experience of being with a ‘losing’ lover with the experience of unsustainable happiness.

annotations: Every night, baby, that’s where I go

In this line, Mitski uses the word “baby”. Many people, including myself, believe that this song could be talking about unhealed trauma from a past relationship which was unhealthy. However, Mitski uses the word baby which means she probably still cares about her past lover. The pearl could be talking about the past relationship and the “glow” is all the good things about the relationship standing out to mitski. Mitski still calls the person “baby” which is something that lovers call each other. This could show us that mitski thinks that the other persons not done anything wrong and she could still love them.
In a more recent song, The only heartbreaker, she talks about how during the relationship she felt like she was the only one making mistakes and in her eyes the other person was perfect

There’s a hole that you fill
 You fill, you fill

The hole refers to the emotional damage she sustained from her past (perhaps from a past toxic relationship). Her current lover helps her heal, thus filling the hole. It is difficult to let go of past trauma, and she apologizes to her lover for being distant and withdrawn due to her experiences. However, the bridge suggests that she is allowing her lover to help fill the hole, a positive juxtaposition from the rest of the song.

Alternatively, the sense that the partner “filling a hole" is not necessarily a good thing; the line may refer to the fact that she’s using her partner to cope. They’re filling up a space left behind by something else, and even trying their hardest it seems this isn’t enough. She’s pushing them away at the same time she claims to still want them. Acknowledging that they’re growing weary of her evasiveness, but without doing anything to address the root of the issue. This withdrawal is causing their relationship to be strained and she can see it happening, yet her attention is still consumed by things that represent her trauma rather than anything that might help her recover from it.
Every night, baby, that’s where I go

This suggests that the narrator has nightmares or episodes where she mentally “goes” to remember or relive her trauma, as she can’t let go of it. Night terrors are associated with trauma and long-term stress.
You love me so hard and I still can’t sleep

She can’t sleep because she’s still worried about the relationship – she still sees it as a war and thinks to herself, “You’re growing tired of me.” In this song she reflects on how she feels in relationships, and shows self awareness that relates to so much of her writing; this line is a great encapsulation of this phenomenon.

This line also refers to the toxicity of the relationship — so often, people who are stuck in abusive relationships begin to believe that abuse is a way of showing love. She’s doing this same thing, thinking that her partner’s hardness is love when, in fact, it might have been cruelty all along — but, now, she can’t let go of the idea that that might have been the best love she could ever get.
And all the things I don’t talk about

Not only is she closed off because of her past trauma, she is also unable to communicate this with her partner. If the partner can’t understand why she is hurting/how she was hurt, there is not much they can do to mend the relationship (so they’re growing tired).
Every night, just to watch it glow

Pearls also symbolize treasure. Whatever is beautiful about them, however, is built around the initial irritant that enters a clam to be coated. Mitski is unable to separate the glow of the old relationship from its irritants. If she wants to watch one glow, she must come into contact with the other. Whether she is longing for the good parts of her last relationship or replaying the bad, these both are surface-level obsessions that keep her shut off from future trauma (and future joy!).

It’s just that I fell in love with a war
 Nobody told me it ended

When you have become accustomed to a toxic relationship, you realize that you’re in love with the chaos – the ups and the downs.

As the relationship ends, her addiction to that war doesn’t, and therefore her emotional unavailability remains.
[Bridge]
In the vocalization leading up to the bridge, she re-uses a hook from a song off her earlier album Lush, aptly titled “Pearl Diver”.
You’re growing tired of me

Extract from an interview with The 405:


‘A Pearl’ really gets me, especially the line “you’re getting tired of me, and all the things that I don’t talk about.” The economy of words is great… But I guess the overall message of this song is that it takes time to adjust to peace in a relationship; does that surprise you?

“I think what’s more surprising to me is when you’re OK – but you’re not used to being OK, and when you’ve been unhappy for so long that being unhappy is your norm and what you’re uncomfortable with – so when you’re not unhappy, when you’re finally fine, you don’t know what to do with yourself. You repeat self-destructive behaviours because it’s what you know, it’s what you feel you deserve and what you’re comfortable with. If it’s just your life then you can be as self-destructive as you want, but what makes it complicated is if you have someone else in your life who cares about you, if you’re in a relationship, and you’re supposed to be fine and you have someone asking about you and caring about you, but you just can’t stop being unhappy, because being unhappy is what you want. That feeling of someone else being involved in your wellbeing, and not being able to be well for them.”

Sorry, I don’t want your touch
 It’s not that I don’t want you
 Sorry, I can’t take your touch

People who have experienced toxic relationships often shift their personalities to adapt to the harm that’s being caused to them. As a result, it’s hard to go back to a normal relationship (which now feels lacking), and the person subconsciously ends up seeking out more toxicity.
The person Mitski describes as the narrator’s partner seems to be good for them. Still, the narrator can’t let go of the past relationship and keeps “rolling the pearl”.

description.plain:
Liquid Smooth is the first song on Mitski’s 2012 album, Lush. This song talks about beauty standards for young women. Lyrics like “I’m in my prime” “I’m at my highest peak, I’m ripe” suggest that she is talking about how women in their early 20’s are seen as more desirable.

At the end of the chorus, she says that she is “about to fall.” This lyric and the general tone of the song suggest that she is worried about aging because she will no longer fit within the beauty standards.

song.title: Liquid Smooth

body.plain:
Liquid Smooth is the first song on Mitski’s 2012 album, Lush. This song talks about beauty standards for young women. Lyrics like “I’m in my prime” “I’m at my highest peak, I’m ripe” suggest that she is talking about how women in their early 20’s are seen as more desirable.

At the end of the chorus, she says that she is “about to fall.” This lyric and the general tone of the song suggest that she is worried about aging because she will no longer fit within the beauty standards.

annotations: I’m pulsing,
Pulsing could insinuate being ready, the anticipation of whats coming next but it seemingly never coming. The anxiety of the wait.
Beginning to end
This could show that her anxiety levels could be rising as this feeling isn’t going away. It’s not temporary which shows that the reason why she feels this way has scarred her
My blood is red and unafraid of living

This line could be pointing out that while her blood is “unafraid of living” she is not. She is afraid to grow older and no longer be beautiful, and other lines reflect this feeling, such as “I’m ripe about to fall, capture me”.

How I feel this river rushing through my veins
 With nowhere else to go, it circles ’round
Here, the river references her blood. It “circles” just like the days, years. Time flees and so does her beauty and she’s afraid of losing this tool that makes her powerful.
Or at least take my picture

This lyric implies that she is aware of her fleeting, short-lived status as a beautiful person, in our society which deems women as unattractive as soon as they are 25. In this line, she wants her beauty to be remembered after it fades, she is stating that all of her self-worth is tied to the idea that she is young and beautiful.
I’m liquid smooth, come touch me, too

She tries to describe herself in the most appealing way, similar to the way fruit produce glucose so herbivores enjoy their taste so the seed of the plant can hopefully be spread in an effort to survive.
This can be interpreted in 2 ways, one of which is that she sees herself as something that lives only to serve a biological function, reproduction. Another way is that her beauty is the only card available to her to do anything she deems meaningful, however short lived it may be.

I’m liquid smooth, come touch me, too
 And feel my skin is plump and full of life, I’m in my prime

In these lines and most of the song she doesn’t refer to herself as a person or a human, but only in regards to her body in a biological way. This conveys that the value and appeal of women is often determined through their bodies.
When she makes comments about being in her “prime” and being smooth and full of life, she shows that this beauty and worth is short-lived, as it is intrinsically tied to youth. In her current youthful state, she wants to be touched- shown her value through appreciation of and attraction to her beauty.

I’m beautiful, I know ’cause it’s the season
 But what am I to do with all this beauty?

It’s a critique of society’s valuing of beauty, something that is ultimately temporary according to its standards because as we age we are seen as less beautiful, the song begins by basically saying ‘I’m beautiful, so what, what purpose does it serve?’

Rather unfortunately a lot, as peoples worth and success often hinges on their appearance, something which the following line notes is just a result of biology and something we really have no control over.

Also, the line, “Cause it’s the season” implies that she knows she is beautiful because she is young, and this is her “season” of youth and beauty. It implies that she knows her beauty is not timeless, but finite and fleeting.
I’m at my highest peak, I’m ripe about to fall, capture me

This lyric can be compared to the one ending the previous stanza in terms of how she feels. She says previously that she is just ‘an organism’ and ‘made of chemicals’ and is comparing herself to a fruit in a sense. This lyric speaks about how Mistki wants validation from someone else (such as a romantic partner) while her self-confidence confidence may be lacking.

Biology, I am an organism, I’m chemical
 That’s all, that is all

This seems like a commentary on how patriarchal societies treat women: as objects with an expiration date. Mitski has long grappled with the idea of beauty as a commodity and how, just like the other physical properties she lists, being beautiful is in itself a good one might distribute for other things (like power).

I want you16Embed

description.plain: ‘I Want You’ tells the poetic heartbreak of a relationship that was one-sided. The song includes lyrics that explain how there was an attempt to make the relationship last, however with lacking support this led to its inevitable downfall. Mitski’s melancholic vocals portray a tone to the listener, one that is filled with a despairing plea, an exhausted attempt to save their relationship one last time with the words, “I want you”.

song.title: I Want You

album.full_title: Retired from Sad, New Career in Business by Mitski
album.name: Retired from Sad, New Career in Business

body.plain: ‘I Want You’ tells the poetic heartbreak of a relationship that was one-sided. The song includes lyrics that explain how there was an attempt to make the relationship last, however with lacking support this led to its inevitable downfall. Mitski’s melancholic vocals portray a tone to the listener, one that is filled with a despairing plea, an exhausted attempt to save their relationship one last time with the words, “I want you”.

annotations:
You’re in the house
 And I am here in the car
 I just need a quiet place
 Where I can scream
 How I love you

This line could be Mitski expressing how she is leaving her partner behind and moving on as they stay. Since the relationship is shown to be toxic and unrequited, she describes how she longs to tell them that she loves them but doesn’t want them to hear. This could be corresponding to her wanting to move on.

We’re starting over
 And I love you, darling
 And I am done, dear

The phrase “We’re starting over” could allude to the fact that this relationship, in some ways, is toxic, and is in a loop, or that they are starting our as friends, and not lovers. However, the former seems more likely as the previous lyrics “You’re coming back / And it’s the end of the word” shows how this person’s return is detrimental to the speaker.

The following two lines “And I love you, darling / And I am done, dear” have an anaphora of “and” : as if the speaker is listing what she feels, as if they are trying to make an excuse. The use of the two pet names “darling” and “dear” show how, despite how bad the partner may be, the speaker still holds them dear to their heart. However, the final verse of this Pre-Chorus of “I am done, dear” demonstrates how the speaker is finally ready to accept that this person is not good for them ; how it is time for them to let go.

I hold one card
 That I can’t use
 But I want you

Mitski is likely referencing the popular English phrase, “hold your cards” or “holding your cards close” which speaks to card games like Poker and other gambling games. The phrase is typically used to mean “being cautious of revealing your true intentions or feelings,” and Mitski feels she “can’t use” her card (which context reveals to be her love for the song’s subject), but that’s not what she wants.

You’re coming back
 And it’s the end of the world

She clearly wants him, but she also has reasons to be apprehensive about the relationship. Perhaps she knows that he doesn’t want her like she wants him, and she knows she won’t be able to resist him, which will eventually lead to her having to get over him all over again. Maybe, while there were good memories, she is thinking about how bad they really were for each other.

While part of her is glad that she is going to see him, she feels like the world may come crashing down on her if she had to deal with all the complicated feelings she has around this person.

I want you
 I want you

There is often a reflexion on wanting as opposed to needing and loving in Mitski’s songs. The song ends, after saying “How I love you”, with “I want you”.

The fact that she settles at the end of the song with stating “I want you” rather than repeating “I love you” may be a reflexion on how she desires him, she wants him like one wants an unattainable dream. She “wants” him in her life rather than needs him. She wants him more than she loves him.

I found you
 I found the door
 But when I stepped through
 There was no floor

This may a reference to Mitski’s earlier song “Door”.

The metaphor could mean that once she thought she’d managed to get him to open up about himself, she only found that the person had so much more hidden from her that she felt disoriented in the relationship.

description.plain:
Brand New City is the third track off of Mitski’s debut album, LUSH. The song follows a similar theme to Liquid Smooth, detailing the overarching feeling of being “in your prime” but only dreading the fall yet to come, in which both physical and mental condition begin to decay due to both aging and settling into a so-called societal norm. It also details the feeling that one should’ve succeeded earlier in life and it’s now impossible to do so.

Moving to a new city is done by some people to supposedly restart their life – by leaving everything and everyone they’re accustomed to behind and starting from scratch in friends, work, and location. This can work for some, however restarting in a new does not always remove personal matters such as depression, anxiety, or grief.

song.title: Brand New City

body.plain:
Brand New City is the third track off of Mitski’s debut album, LUSH. The song follows a similar theme to Liquid Smooth, detailing the overarching feeling of being “in your prime” but only dreading the fall yet to come, in which both physical and mental condition begin to decay due to both aging and settling into a so-called societal norm. It also details the feeling that one should’ve succeeded earlier in life and it’s now impossible to do so.

Moving to a new city is done by some people to supposedly restart their life – by leaving everything and everyone they’re accustomed to behind and starting from scratch in friends, work, and location. This can work for some, however restarting in a new does not always remove personal matters such as depression, anxiety, or grief.

annotations:
I think my fate is losing its patience
 I think the ground is pulling me down
 I think my life is losing momentum
 I think my ways are wearing me down

The second verse details two different ways in which Mitski believes a downfall will happen to her and why happiness and success may never happen, with the same structure as the first verse (two lines on one topic, two on another).

The first two involve how time itself is against her, and personality is given to the abstract form of time as it becomes frustrated that she’s not reaching the perceived level of “success” that she could be in the first line, and tries to then literally pull her rather than hold her down in the second, as if she is stuck in the passage of time against her will.

However, the third and fourth line change the subject that she believes is stopping her from being happy and successful to herself. The combination of starting to reach a point where her body should begin to degrade in the third and both her way of living and outlook on life in the fourth are both reasons she thinks are why she’s not happy in life.

Think my brain is rotting in places
 I think my heart is ready to die
 I think my body is falling in pieces
 I think my blood is passing me by

In the first verse, Mitski details multiple negative parts of herself that she’s noticed. In the context of the song title, these could be considered reasons to move to a “brand new city”.

The first two lines relate to depression and the symptoms it causes. The first could refer to memory loss, a symptom of depression that can occur either through treating or living with depression. The second is a double entendre of the heart: referring to the organ and a desire to destroy it due to depression, as the heart is a vital organ required to live, whilst also referring to the heart in terms of relationships – either a want for love or pain due to loneliness, or even both.

The second two lines refer more to the deterioration of the human body as it gets older – once the body is fully grown, it can only start deteriorating due to the fact it’s no longer growing, hence my body is falling in pieces representing the degradation of the body and my blood is passing me by inferring the flow of time – Mitski may want to hang on to the current moment, however blood must keep moving around the body.

For context, Lush was released in 2012, when Mitski was 21. Whilst the human body usually doesn’t decay until later in life, it’s a common concern among young adults that they haven’t made the most of the present when they think they should physically and mentally be able to, and that they’ll only grow to regret wasting such time in later life. This is obviously not true, despite feeling like it is – success can come at any point in life.

Honey, what’d you take? What’d you take?
 Honey, look at me
 Tell me what you took, what’d you take?

This repeated group of lines has multiple simultaneous interpretations.

In one interpretation of Mitski as the caregiver, the protagonist’s Honey, clearly someone important to her, has ‘taken’ something ie: a drug. The protagonist tries to care for them, and so says ‘look at me,’ out of concern and to reassure.

However, if ‘take’ is interpreted as more like theft, ie: what did you take from me, the protagonist’s ‘honey’ subsequently becomes an expression of  hurt or scorn. The protagonist’s loved one will not look at them out of shame or to not acknowledge their guilt.

These double meanings are likely intentional, given Mitski’s other works' themes of conflicting identity, such as conflicting expressions of internalised anger and expectations of female caregiving roles in relationships. This is also supported by the themes of unraveling identity throughout the lyrics.

But if I gave up on being pretty, I wouldn’t know how to be alive
 I should move to a brand new city and teach myself how to die

This line suggests the self-destructive nature of Mitski’s “long life obsession” as she explains in this tweet:



If she gave up on trying to be attractive she would lose her sense of power, which she has built for a long time and is dependent on. By moving to a “brand new city” she’s accepting the fact that her life is slowing and this obsession is not healthy or helping her move (as shown in previous lines). That if being pretty is how she learnt to “live”, she’ll just have to learn to “die”.
